results.title: Atoms for peace (U.S.S.R.)
results.creator_credit: D Bogolepov and Moscow Popular Science Film Studio
results.brief_description: Illustrates the peaceful use of atomic energy in the USSR and shows the first atomic power plant in the USSR. The program explains the basic processes involved in nuclear fission and the safety procedures which protect workers. Demonstrates the use of isotopes in medicine, especially in cancer treatment and also the application of atomic energy in industry: improved plastics, oil exploration, detection of flaws in casting and welded seams, use of tracers in checking the condition of blast furnaces and quality control in metal production. The research potential of atomic installations is explored.

results.title: Atoms for peace (Sweden)
results.brief_description: Shows how Sweden, though it is a small country, has become a world leader in the peaceful uses of atomic energy. Examples and advantages of nuclear power generation for the production of electricity and heat and use of radioactive isotopes for industry and medicine are presented. No other credits available.

results.title: Atomic achievement
results.creator_credit: John Reeve, Anthony Gilkison and Rayant Pictures
results.brief_description: An account of Britain’s vast nuclear power program for a new industrial era, and of progress to date. Operational centres visited by the film include Calder Hall, the first full-scale nuclear power station; the great atomic research centre at Harwell; the atomic factories at Springfields, Capenhurst and Windscale; and the “fast breeder-reactor” under construction at Dounreay. Animated diagrams explain the working of a nuclear reactor.

results.title: Atlantic link
results.creator_credit: Jack Greenwood and Film Producers Guild
results.brief_description: This film traces the laying of the first transatlantic submarine telephone cable, made possible by the cooperation of technologists and engineers in the United Kingdom, the United States and Canada. Describes the routing of landlines on both sides of the Atlantic; the drama and precision involved in the laying of cables between Britain and Newfoundland.

results.title: Atlantic community: introducing Portugal
results.creator_credit: Europa Telefilm and North Atlantic Treaty Organization
results.brief_description: Describes the country and the people of Portugal - geographical features, historical development and achievements, economic life, occupations of the people, and social customs. Explains briefly the role of Portugal in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. Narrated by Robert Beatty.

results.title: Athletics: the long jump
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sports training film series”.
Daley Thompson, Britain’s greatest ever all round athlete, shows a variety of jumping, hopping and bounding activities that condition the jumper.

results.title: Single sculling techniques
results.creator_credit: Michael Johns, Elizabeth Isaacs and Dan Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sports training film series”.
Slow motion and freeze-frame photography is used to demonstrate common faults in sculling techniques, and showing the correct techniques. Excellent film with very good commentary.

results.title: The Shot
results.creator_credit: Peter Delfgou, Elizabeth Isaacs and Dan Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sports training film series”.
This film on shot put shows how muscular force should be applied through the body to the shot. It demonstrates training and warm up procedures which should be used prior to the competition throw. From the series “Athletic training”.

results.title: Strength training for sport
results.creator_credit: Paul Foxall, Elizabeth Isaacs and Dan Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sports training film series”
The explosion of new athletic records has largely come about through strength training. The training program must strengthen all muscle groups. The various strength training techniques and exercises are demonstrated by top athletes.
